postContent:
GPT is a power tool. Judgment is still the main Product manager job.

Iâ€™ve been reviewing a lot of PRDs recently, and Iâ€™ve noticed something worrying.
Some product managers are now using GPT to drive their thinking instead of support it.
The result? Documents that check every box of a PRD templateâ€¦ but are full of confusion. To a junior PM, it looks polished. To an experienced eye, itâ€™s mostly noise.

To be clear: GPT is extremely powerful. We use it daily. But like any power tool, the outcome depends on the craftsperson. When GPT leads, it can produce confident structure without correct substanceâ€”and thatâ€™s hard to detect if youâ€™re early in your career.

Where GPT shines
-Evidence gathering: pull prior art, benchmarks, and user quotes.
-Synthesis: compress interviews/notes into themes and edge cases.
-Exploration: generate alternative framings, risks, and test scenarios.
-Communication: first drafts of release notes, FAQs, checklists.

What you should not outsource
-Problem definition: who is the user, whatâ€™s the job, what hurts now.
-Context + constraints: compliance, data realities, org priorities.
-Prioritization and trade-offs: what we will not build and why.
Decision ownership: success metrics, guardrails, and accountability.

A simple review test I use
Few sentence problem (no AI): if you canâ€™t state it cleanly, youâ€™re not ready to draft.
Evidence trace: every user scenario ties to a source or observation.
Decisions > templates: I look for rationale, not headings.

GPT should amplify your clarity, not simulate it. If the first time you feel â€œclearâ€ is after the AI draft, thatâ€™s a warning sign.
To young professionals (PMs and beyond): master the thinking, then use GPT to accelerate it. Tools compound good judgment; they canâ€™t replace it.
â€” Curious to hear how other product teams are seeing the impact of AI in their world.
author: Ankit Ratan

postContent:
Building a company like Signzy means spending most of my time deep in the world of technology, compliance, AI, and risk. Itâ€™s fast-paced. High-stakes. Constantly evolving.
But thereâ€™s another side to my life â€” much quieter, but just as meaningful.
For the past few years, my family ( Moni Gupta, Aloka Kumar Kulshrestha) has been running an initiative called Seva Setu. Itâ€™s not a startup. Thereâ€™s no pitch deck. No VC funding. Just a simple mission: serve those who are often overlooked â€” children from underserved communities, the elderly in care homes, even animals in need.
This past year, Seva Setu has supported students with study kits, helped children access daily nutritious meals, enabled access to quality education, cared for elders, and looked after cows in gaushalas.
Itâ€™s not loud work, but worth it.
Whenever the intensity of building Signzy feels overwhelming, Seva Setu reminds me of a different kind of impact - one measured not in product metrics or scale, but in human moments. 
Weâ€™ve put together a short annual report to capture some of what weâ€™ve been able to do this year. If youâ€™d like to take a look or just know more, here it is: Seva_Setu_Annual_Report_2024-25
Itâ€™s work that grounds me. And reminds me why we build anything in the first place. Hope this encourages all of us to contribute to society in meaningful ways.
#SevaSetu #Signzy #SocialImpact #Compassion #LeadershipWithHeart #GivingBack

postContent:
ğŸ§  Are LLMs just pattern matchers? A recent debate has reignited this foundational AI question.

It started with an Apple research paper that argued todayâ€™s AI systemsâ€”including large language modelsâ€”are not truly â€œreasoning.â€ Theyâ€™re just doing statistical pattern matching at scale. No abstraction, no understanding, no causalityâ€”just very good autocomplete.

In response, Ilya Sutskever (co-founder of OpenAI) delivered a lecture where he flipped the script:

> â€œOur brains are also just giant pattern matchers.â€



His point? Intelligence doesnâ€™t require symbolic logic or explicit reasoning steps. The human brain learns from patterns tooâ€”associations, reinforcement, feedback. And LLMs are perhaps walking the same evolutionary path, just digitally.

But hereâ€™s a missing piece that neither side emphasizes enough:
The substrate matters.

ğŸ§  Human brains are massively parallel, analog, and energy efficient. Neurons can fire with infinite gradations, and billions of them operate simultaneously. Pattern matching in the brain can involve emotional nuance, parallel thoughts, and contextual awarenessâ€”all happening together.

ğŸ’» AI systems, on the other hand, run on silicon chips. Even with GPUs and TPUs, theyâ€™re fundamentally linear, digital, and binary. A transistor can be ON or OFF. Parallelism is simulated, and multitasking is expensive. When an LLM generates a sentence, it's not juggling multiple perspectives in the way a human doesâ€”itâ€™s walking one path at a time, very fast.

So yes, maybe both brains and LLMs are pattern matchers.
But only one of them is doing it in wetware, with organic nuance and infinite resolution. The other is stuck in silicon.

And perhaps, that difference still matters more than we think.
author: Ankit Ratan

postContent:
API vs MCP vs A2A â€” Whatâ€™s the Difference, and Why It Matters
Thereâ€™s a lot of buzz around new AI frameworks like MCP and A2A, and many people are asking â€” how are these different from traditional APIs?

Letâ€™s break it down with simple examples:
1. APIs (Application Programming Interfaces)
 APIs are how different apps talk to each other â€” especially when theyâ€™re owned by different teams or companies.
Example:
 Your app wants to check the credit score of a user. You hit an external credit bureauâ€™s API, which returns a score.
 The bureau decides what data to expose, how often, and in what format.
APIs are great for external world integration â€” clean, secure, versioned. But they require agreement, documentation, and often strict access control.
 You donâ€™t see whatâ€™s behind the curtain â€” you just use whatâ€™s offered.

2. MCP (Model-Context Protocol)
 Introduced by Anthropic, MCP allows LLMs to interact with external tools and data via a standardized interface. Itâ€™s still a one-model world, but you feed it structured access to plugins and databases.
Example:
 An LLM helping a customer support agent might use MCP to look up order history, check return status, or send a refund â€” all through tools connected via this common protocol.
MCP is about making a single AI model smarter by giving it controlled access to context and tools.
 It reduces the need to hard-code every integration.

3. A2A (Agent-to-Agent Framework)
 This is where things shift from integration to collaboration. With A2A, different AI agents can talk to each other, negotiate, and complete tasks together â€” even across systems â€” without needing formal APIs exposed.
Example:
A lightweight agent on your app checks user inputs
It passes the data to a document-verifying agent
That agent flags inconsistencies and triggers a risk-check agent
All this happens internally, without each system exposing APIs or standardizing requests
Itâ€™s like RPA â€” but no humans in the loop, and far more intelligence.

The Big Shift
API: You tell me what you expose, and Iâ€™ll write code to use it.
MCP: Iâ€™m one smart AI, and I know how to use tools if you give me handles.
A2A: Iâ€™m part of a team of smart agents. Weâ€™ll talk, figure it out, and get the job done â€” no need to call IT to expose a new API.

This opens up exciting new possibilities:
-Teams donâ€™t have to standardize every backend operation into an API
-On-device agents can handle more on the edge
-Internal workflows become more autonomous and scalable

The AI architecture of the future wonâ€™t be a single genius model â€” itâ€™ll be a team of capable agents talking to each other.
Let me know what you think â€” or if youâ€™ve started playing with these ideas. Would love to hear more use cases.
author: Ankit Ratan

postContent:
Google just launched something interesting in the AI space called A2A (Agent-to-Agent). Itâ€™s a framework where different AI agents can talk to each other, work together, and check each otherâ€™s work.
Instead of one big model doing everything, A2A lets multiple smaller agents handle different tasks â€” like writing code, reviewing it, and deciding what to do next. Kind of like how real teams operate.
Whatâ€™s exciting here is that this is not just about breaking one prompt into parts (like MCP does). In MCP, you're still driving one model to do multiple tasks in a structured way â€” like giving it a checklist. But with A2A, you're creating actual independent agents, each focused on their own specialty, talking and collaborating like co-workers. Itâ€™s a more modular, flexible setup.
Another interesting angle: A2A could enable lightweight agents on the edge (like inside your mobile app) to talk to more powerful agents running on the backend. That could mean faster responses, less data transfer, and better privacy â€” especially useful in customer-facing apps.
In the customer onboarding space, this opens up a lot. You often need:
One agent to recommend the right financial product
Another to verify documents and extract data
A third to assess customer risk
With A2A, these specialized agents can be trained once and reused across different workflows â€” no need to build new agents or clunky rule-switching logic every time something changes.
Weâ€™re exploring how this could help improve our own onboarding and document automation flows. Early days, but it feels like a solid step toward building smarter, more adaptable AI systems.
author: Ankit Ratan

postContent:
Beyond Fancy Ice Creams: A Wake-Up Call for Indiaâ€™s Innovation Ecosystem

Union Minister Piyush Goyal recent remarks at Startup Mahakumbhâ€”mentioning â€œfancy ice creamsâ€ and â€œhyperfast groceriesâ€â€”sparked strong reactions across Indiaâ€™s startup world.

But perhaps the criticism should be seen less as dismissal and more as deliberate tough love. Goyal, one of Indiaâ€™s most effective communicators, likely chose his words to provoke reflectionâ€”not discourage innovation. Like a parent urging a child to aim higher, his message is clear: India must prioritize deep tech innovation if it wants to lead globally.

While consumption-driven startups have created jobs, attracted FDI, and modernized services, they often reorganize existing spending patterns rather than build long-term capability. True nation-changing innovationâ€”semiconductors, robotics, EVs, AIâ€”requires patient investment, research, and ecosystem-wide support.

Countries like South Korea (electronics), Israel (cybersecurity), and China (EVs & automation) made deliberate, long-term bets on deep techâ€”and are reaping the benefits.

The responsibility doesnâ€™t lie with founders alone. Government, academia, investors, and corporate leaders must work in concert. That means more public funding for research, deeper academia-industry collaboration, and a culture that celebrates solving hard problemsâ€”not just scaling fast.

India doesnâ€™t need to abandon consumer innovation. But we must balance it with bold, future-defining bets. The next chapter of our startup story should be about building the technology the world usesâ€”not just delivering it faster.

If this speech makes us pause and ask: What kind of innovation will define India in 2047?, then it has served its purpose.

Letâ€™s celebrate our progressâ€”but also raise our ambitions.
author: Ankit Ratan

postContent:
ğŸš€ How UPI Killed Splitwise in India (But Itâ€™s Still Alive in the US!) ğŸ’¸
Remember the days when splitting a bill meant long calculations, awkward reminders, and the dreaded "I'll pay you later" texts? Apps like Splitwise thrived because paying back was a painâ€”logging into a bank on a desktop, adding payees, and waiting for transfers to process.
Then came UPI in Indiaâ€”and overnight, bill-splitting apps became almostâ€¦ irrelevant. ğŸ’€
ğŸ“Š UPI Revolution in Numbers:
 âœ… 8.9 billion transactions in April 2024 ğŸš€
 âœ… 85%+ market share dominated by PhonePe & Google Pay
 âœ… Instant, 24/7 transfers with no need for third-party apps
Now, you just scan, pay, and move onâ€”no need to "split later" when you can pay instantly. Apps like PhonePe and Google Pay even offer built-in bill-splitting features.
Meanwhile, in the USâ€¦ ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸
 Without a widely adopted real-time payment system like UPI, apps like Splitwise, Venmo, and SettleUp still thrive. People track expenses, send Venmo requests, and wait for money to land in their bank accounts.
ğŸ’¡ Lesson?
 Tech adoption isnâ€™t just about innovationâ€”itâ€™s about removing friction. India leapfrogged the bill-splitting era by making payments instant, while the US still leans on dedicated apps.
What do you think? Will the US see a UPI-like disruption, or will Splitwise & Venmo stay strong? Letâ€™s discuss! ğŸ‘‡
author: Ankit Ratan

postContent:
Some legacies arenâ€™t just remembered, theyâ€™re lived every single day.

For 90 years, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has done just that. Quietly shaping the way India banks, transacts, and trusts its financial system.

From coins in our pockets to the tap of a phone, the RBIâ€™s journey is stitched into the fabric of our daily lives.

As we continue celebrating #RBIWeek at Signzy, todayâ€™s spotlight is on the milestones that made this institution a force of stability, innovation, and progress â€” one policy at a time.

Whether it was introducing Asiaâ€™s first deposit insurance to protect small depositors, driving credit towards agriculture and small businesses through priority sector lending, or nationalizing banks to make financial services accessible to millions â€” each milestone shaped the way India banks today ğŸ’ª

In recent years, the RBI has continued to adapt â€” enabling UPIâ€™s rapid growth into a global payments benchmark, making onboarding simpler with Video KYC, and exploring the future of money through digital currency pilots. Its scale-based framework for NBFC regulation and the formation of the Monetary Policy Committee have further strengthened the systemâ€™s resilience.

Through changing times and new challenges, the RBIâ€™s role has remained clear â€” enabling progress while safeguarding stability 

Let's dive deeper in their journey ğŸ‘‡

#90YearsOfRBI #SignzyRBIWeek #RBI90Years

postContent:
The Modern Sudoku: Spotting AI-Generated Fakes in a Digital World ğŸ§©ğŸ”

Remember the feeling of solving a tricky Sudoku puzzle? You analyze patterns, rule out impossibilities, and use logic to find whatâ€™s real.
Now, imagine that game applied to every image you see online.
From too-perfect cityscapes to flawless portraits, AI-generated images are becoming harder to distinguish from reality. But just like Sudoku, spotting them is about identifying inconsistencies:
âœ”ï¸ A street with warped reflections? AI-generated.
âœ”ï¸ A celebrity in a bizarre setting, yet with perfectly even lighting? Likely fake.
âœ”ï¸ Hands with extra fingers or earrings that donâ€™t match? Classic AI slip-ups.
As deepfake and generative AI tools improve, the real challenge isnâ€™t just creating imagesâ€”itâ€™s detecting them. And while AI-generated content can be fun and creative, it also raises big questions about misinformation, authenticity, and trust.
The next time an image makes you pause, treat it like a puzzleâ€”because in todayâ€™s digital world, verification is the new problem-solving skill.
Have you ever spotted an AI-generated image in the wild? What gave it away? Letâ€™s discuss! ğŸ‘‡
